metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case challenged the legality of tariffs imposed by the Trump administration under the Internati...

target:
This case challenged the legality of tariffs imposed by the Trump administration under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). On May 29, 2025, Chapter1 LLC, a Nevada-based skincare business, filed this suit in the U.S. Court of International Trade seeking a refund of $22,953.50 in duties it paid under a series of executive orders that imposed tariffs ranging from 10% to 145% on imports from China. Represented by Gerstein Harrow LLP, the plaintiff alleged that the tariffs were not authorized by IEEPA, were imposed in violation of statutory and constitutional limits, and had been declared unlawful by the court one day earlier in V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump [../../../../case/46396/].

Chapter1 had imported a custom-made machine from China on May 5, 2025, and paid nearly double the value of the machine in duties. It filed this action on behalf of itself and a proposed class of all importers who paid tariffs under the challenged executive orders. The plaintiff sought class certification, a declaratory judgment, and either a refund or money judgment.

On the same day, the plaintiff also moved for summary judgment (SJ) and for class certification. The summary judgment motion relied heavily on the court’s ruling in V.O.S., arguing that the legal issues had already been resolved and no facts were in dispute.

On June 27, 2025, Chapter1 voluntarily dismissed the case under Rule 41(a)(1)(A)(i). The court clerk entered the dismissal the same day. No answer was filed and no judicial ruling was issued on the merits.

The case is closed.

Represented by Gerstein Harrow LLP, the plaintiff alleged that the tariffs were not authorized by IEEPA, were imposed in violation of statutory and constitutional limits, and had been declared unlawful by the court one day earlier in V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump [../../../../case/46396/].

Constitutional and statutory claims that the tariffs violated constitutional and statutory limits.
Cause of action relies on precedent: V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump.
International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA)
